Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.3) 7 – 9.1 (9.3) × (3.2) 3.7 – 4.9 (5.4) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.7 – 2 (2.4); N = 30; Me = 8 × 4.4 µm; Qe = 1.8”

results.notes:
Growing on a hillside near Quercus alba, Quercus bicolor, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carya ovata, Acer saccharum, Prunus serotina and Ulmus sp. Fruiting bodies collected 7.4 (cap) x 8 cm (stem) and 7.2 (cap) x 4.1 cm (stem) respectively. Caps yellow with orange to reddish-brown areas. Caps were dry when found but were covered with adhering debris. Cap margins greenish. Stems with marginate bulbs. Stems purple with some yellowish areas. Cortina remnants forming a ring on the stem. Context not staining when cut. Cap context purple in a layer above the gills and white above that layer. Stem context purple. Gills purple except for a rusty brown spore deposit. Odor indistinct. Taste of cap slightly mealy but otherwise indistinct. Cap surface mild when licked. ~60% KOH dark purple on reddish-brown portion of cap (meant to use 5% KOH instead). Spore measurements: (11.5) 13.3 – 14.1 (15.9) x (6.9) 7.5 – 7.8 (8.5) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.7 – 1.8 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 13.7 × 7.7 µm ; Qe = 1.8

results.notes:
Solitary fruiting body growing along the edge of the trail near Pseudotsuga menziesii var. glauca, Picea sp. (P. pungens or P. engelmannii), Populus tremuloides and Ameliancher alnifolia.

Total height of basidiocarp: 5.8 cm (4.8 stem + 1.0 cap).

Lamellae greenish yellow except for a thin brown zone where they meet the stipe apex; sinuate with deep notches; ~0.5 deep at deepest; ~2.4 cm long at longest. Pairs of full-length lamellae separated by 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae. ~104 full-length lamellae total on basidiocarp (calculated by counting number of full-length lamellae in rough 1/4 portion of basidiocarp and multiplying by 4).

Stipe pale yellow and dry; 2.6 cm wide at apex; ~1.9 cm wide at midpoint. Base of stipe enlarged and somewhat bulbous with adhering debris; appearing marginate in dried specimen; 2.1 cm wide at widest portion; 1.7 cm wide at very base.

Cap slimy; 6.4 cm wide. Center of cap reddish-brown. Grayish zone between the reddish-brown center and the purple margin.

Context white in cap and stem.

Taste and odor indistinct.

5% KOH dark red on cap and pale yellow on context.

Cap and stem surface turned red as they dried.

Photos taken 2 days after collecting except for photos with 5% KOH, which were taken 3 days after.

results.notes:
On sandstone bedrock, north-west facing orientation.

Thallus consists of a white, rather thick rimose crust that is K- and C-. Medulla white, supposed to be dark blue in Iodine, but I didn’t get any reaction observed under dissecting scope at 20x or at 100x in the compound scope. Epihymenium black with aeruginose tinge extending down into hymenium. Hymenium hyaline I+blue (Lugol’s), hypothecium yellowish. Pycnidia common with a black slit-like ostiole (described as “graphidoid”). Conidia straight, bacilliform, 8-11 × 1-1.5µm.

Spores 8/ascus, simple, hyaline, broadly ellipsoid, average 11.9×6.6 (n=6).
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
On sandstone bedrock.

Thallus grey with convex areoles, often angular, with white crusty pruina, K-. Apothecia one per areole, overtaking the areole, concave with black disk and no pruina. Thalline margin often dark. Hymenium hyaline to dingy yellowish, hypothecium slightly darker dingy, epihymenium dark with green tints, K+reddish brown. Paraphyses moniliform. Pycnidia common, showing as a small black round ostiole on the thallus. Conidia filiform, average 22.2µm (n=5).

Spores 8/ascus, simple, ellipsoid, hyaline. Average 19.6×12.8 (n=4).

Same general locality as observation 252927, and nearly identical morphology.
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

Habitat: mixed mountain forest, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies dominant trees; steep mountain slope, southwest aspect; calcareous ground; in half shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 3-5 deg C, elevation 1.230 m (4.040 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: forest soil and fallen Fagus sylvatica leaves.

Place: Upper Trenta valley, southwest of Vršič pass, above 33rd switchback of Vršič alpine road, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Mycetinis alliaceus is easy to recognize by its very slender growth, surprisingly tough and pliant stipe and, before all, strong smell on onions/garlic. It is a quite common species in Trenta valley and also easy to spot. Growing solitary. SP abundant, white.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Location is upper Morro Creek along Highway 41 West, between Morro Bay and Atascadero.
Habitat is riparian, with a dense canopy of live oak, California bay, sycamore and willow. The specific location is a deep shaded canyon.
Substrate is non-calcareous rock situated at or just above the high flood line of the creek. Probably does not become inundated.

Same location but different specimen as observation 265382.

Thallus is a thin flat topped rimose crust, greenish brown with white mottling, K-. Apothecia black with faint brownish tones in the disk, biatorine, flat with slightly raised rim to somewhat convex, losing the rim. Hymenium hyaline, IKI+blue, hypothecium dingy, epihymenium reddish to golden brown, K-.

Spores 8/ascus, grey to brown, 1-septate, ellipsoid, “little unhappy faces” 18.9×9.9, 22.9×10.3, 20.1×10.5µm.

results.notes:
Habitat- Grass picnic area, with mature aspen trees
Cap- 11cm, dark brown, incurved maybe inrolled margin, mostly flat
Flesh- Very thin, almost non existent
Gills- Very uneven and very deep, tan to brown, adnate,
Stem- 5cm long, 3.5cm wide, fibrillose exterior, with central spongy mass separating from exterior
Odor/taste- smells like a radish.
Spore color- could not obtain print, but evidence shows white.
Microscopic notes- not available at this time.
Chemical reactions- not available at this time.
Misc. notes- several other specimens, likely same species were growing in proximity, some up to 20cm caps. This specimen seemed to be the freshest of the bunch as the pictures would suggest. Originally thought Hebeloma but white spores would suggest otherwise.

results.notes:
NEED HELP IDENTIFYING:

I’ve researched every *ocybe, the Lepistas, Leucopaxillus & numerous others. I can not match it. In fact, I thought I almost had it with Omphaliaster ianthinocystis until I saw it grows on wood in the subtropics.

Microscopically, I have been unable to find basidia as the lamellae were so thickly covered with spores.

Here’s the description:

Caps: 5-8 cm, centrally depressed, incurved margin, lobed, dry, smooth, off-white with lilac overtones.

Flesh: off-white like cap, 7-8 mm thick, slowly stains pinkish.

Gills: deep lilac/purple, distant, broad, numerous lamellulae, thick, decurrent, somewhat serrated, (some white veil remnants).

Stem: 9 cm x 1.5 cm at apex, 2 cm at semi-bulbous base, whitish with lilac overtones, curved, striate, where damaged it’s bright lilac/purple.

Spore Print: white.

Spores: 4-6 µ, globose, nodulose-tuberculate.

Habitat: Terrestrial in the middle of grassy lane in which one side is strictly pine while the other side of the lane is oak with some beech.

results.notes:
This was something out of my usual obervations and resulted to be a “double fungi”, i.e. a fungus that is present in two forms: anamorph and telemorph, that is sometimes referred as the holomorph. That fact only “de per si” is new to me.
Mainly due to historic reasons, the anamorph and the telemorph have different scientific names. Either of them are completely new to me and I’m still learning how to observe them under the microscope. The identification process is not yet complete, because the data obtained from microscopy doesn’t allow to do it.
These specimens were treated in a topic at AscoFrance:
http://www.ascofrance.fr/search_forum/46891
where with the help of Martin Bemmann, the name proposed here was suggested and seeming to be the best choice: “Gibberella cf. zeae”. The anamorph of Gibberella zeae is commonly referred as Fusarium graninearum, but there seem to exist many synonyms of either of them, anamorph and telemorph versions (in a
future message I will mention some). Since then I have continued to make microscopy on the specimens, which are consitent with those obtained at the time of that post, but meanwhile I got new insights on the microstrutures, that I will display at this observation and that will be updated as long as I will have new data to add.
Giberella zeae is characterized, among other features, by the 3-septate spores; it happens that in my preliminary micro observations I could only see non-septate spores; after, with the help of cotton blue in latic acid, I could see many 1-septate spores and a single ascus where co-exist 1-, 2- and 3-septate spores (just one of this latter type, to be precise). Thus, at this stage I will not present specific photos of the spores and postpone for future updates to do it, hopping that, meanwhile, I can have some progress in this matter. On the other hand, I’m astonish with the beauty of the stuctures already observed and could not go further without giving notice of them. So, this observation will be a kind of “working in progress”.

I still had no possibilty of going back to the place of the observation to see if more specimens exist there, and maybe at a different maturation stage. I will try to do it
soon.

Let me now refer some other features of the species under observation:
- Ascomata growing on the wood of a living shrub – Coronilla minima (also identified by Martim Bemmann at the AscoFrance topic), having perithecia as fruiting bodies that grow in groups, but without forming a real stroma;
- The perithecia, which are very small (~ 200 microns) have the special property of being blue under transmited light, with a very rich wall structure;
- the hyphae around the perithecia are deeply divided and septate;
- the conidia, present in almost all part of the slides observed, are septate (mostly with 5 septa, but this is variable); in some of the observations, some tufts of conidia
were present in the neighbourwoods of the perithecia (bottom part of them);
- Within the perithecia, the hymenium consists of asci, appearing to be deeply guttulate both from the inside as well as from the outside, which makes it very difficult to observe them together with the spores inside, and chains of globose juxtaposed cells ending with a clavate or more or less cylindrical element;

All the above mentioned features are illustrated with photos attached to this observation.

have found this a few times now. suspecting it is some parasitic xylariaceous thing. the stems are quite tough but flexible, smooth and shiny below, hairy near the enlarged fertile head, always extending rather deep underground, sometimes in a bouquet of five to ten or more individuals, sometimes sparser, attached to roots or free living in soil (difficult to say). the one collection I have seen with mature perithecia had only three or four, and large ones like this, the black ostioles of which just barely poked above just as white and cottony a surface layer as seen here. it breaks from xylariaceous tradition by maintaining this seemingly asexual surface appearance at maturity, but really, what else could this be?

results.notes:
Code: Bot_538/2011_DSC8845

Habitat: Fagus sylvatica forest with some Picea abies; moderately steep mountain slope, north aspect, calcareous ground, in shade, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-7 deg C, elevation 1.000 m (3.300 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: a highly rotten trunk of probably Fagus sylvatica lying on ground.

Place: Northeast slopes of Mt. Kobariški Stol mountain ridge, near the top of Prvi Hum hill southwest of village Žaga, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Chlorociboria aeruginascens is a small but stunning colored fungus. It stains decaying wood beautifully blue-green by the production of the pigment xylindein. The stained wood has been used by woodworkers for centuries to provide the blue-green colors in their marvelous inlaid intarsia designs (see Ref.1).

Two morphologically indistinguishably similar species of Chlorociboria exist: Chlorociboria aeruginascens and Chlorociboria aeruginosa. They can be distinguished only microscopically, mainly by the size of their ascospores. The spores of Chlorociboria aeruginosa are typically larger than those of C. aeruginascens. Unfortunately, I found no spores and hence it is not sure, which species the pictures show. Since the Chlorociboria aeruginosa is much less frequent in general and also in Slovenia I assume I photographed Chlorociboria aeruginascens. These two fungi are distributed throughout the temperate forests of the world.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
Slo.: škrlatna čašica – Habitat: Hardwood forest, east inclined foot of a mountain, cretaceous clastic rock (flysh) bedrock, in shade, average temperature 8-10 deg C, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, elevation 465 m (1.530 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: buried rotten branches of broadleaved trees covered by a layer of rotten leaves.

Place: Bovec basin, between the church St. Lenart and regional road Bovec- Predel pass, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Bright red cups of Sarcoscypha coccinea are usually the first ‘fungal’ promise of the coming spring and mushroom season in woods around Bovec. Depending on the year these mushrooms can appear loccaly in very large numbers. Some fruitbodies can be quite large, up to 5 cm in diameter and sometimes even more. They are vividly colored and very eye-catching on mostly gray-brown forest floor just after the snow melts. No doubt, one of the most beautiful cup fungi!

There are two species known, which are morphologically indistinguishable: Sarcoscypha coccinea and Sarcoscypha austriaca. They can be reliably separated only microscopically. The dimensions of spores, and to some extent also their shape, and properties of very tiny hairs (if present!) covering other sterile surface of the fruitbodies are decisive for determination. It is believed that Sarcoscypha coccinea is much more common in Slovenia, therefore I believe the determination is most probably correct. However, microscopy hasn’t been done; therefore one cannot exclude that my pictures show other option.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes: GFields behind my house after flood stage rains. This spot hasn’t seen water for awhile and is bursting with fruiting bodies. Normally hot and dry so the specimens don’t stay mint very long. These (hopefully blewitts) were found singularly but in close proximity to one another. Either on the ground on hardwood mulch or attached to some downed cottonwood logs that had been decaying for some time deep purple as if it were a court but gills are tight and spore print is light. Slightly fruity scent and cap is a little tacky when wet.mibimal worm damage but most specimens are small with holes nearby suggesting that they could be getting devoured.

results.notes: If in my first observation of this species, Observation 264099: Coprinopsis tuberosa, the sclerotia formation at the base of the stem was inconspicuous, this time was much bigger. I saw a group of three mushrooms standing together without apparent connection; removing the substracta (dung, possibly of a dog) from their bases I could see black formations – sclerotia – that after cutted revealed a pure white inside. Unfortunately all these happened at home with a poor lighting conditions, since in the field I could not take the desirable photos due to a lack of batteries, and the corresponding photos are miserable (Photo 1, is from that time).; The day after I took some photos of the sclerotia and of the specimens (Photo set 2). In spite of having conserved the mushrooms in the fridge, there was no developement of the specimens and the microscopy failed; only the veil could be well observed and no mature spores. However, I think that it is enough for the identification, since the sclerotia is fairly distinctive.

results.notes: The pine tree where these specimens lived, as well as those in observation 268860, fell some years (at least two) ago, since I recall to see it on the trail existing at the place. Now, going back there, I could see more specimens, all being confined to some 3-4 meters on the main trunk of the tree (which was a big one (more than 30 meters for sure; I don’t know exactly the species, but I took a photo of the pine cones that attached to this observation). The bigger specimens have about 6-7 mm in diameter but there are many small ones with only 1-2 mm. I have looked around and no other evidence of this species in the neighbour trees was found.

results.notes:
Growing near Doug fir.
Caps up to 7.0 cm across and slightly slimy when wet.
No distinct odor before or after drying.
Latex milky white, fairly copious and unchanging.
Stem mostly solid when young to partially hollow.
Taste mild to very slight bitter.
Spore print white.
Spores ~ 7.0-7.3 X 6.8-7.0, mostly globose, with low warts and partial reticulum.
Lots of possibilities but these combinations of characters don’t seem to quite match any one species(?)
If I downplay the taste aspect, these could be the old Lactarius desjardinii species.

results.notes:
Ecology; Growing in rich humus, leaf and stick debris, mainly from the Quercus ilex and Ceratonia siliqua. Both of these trees were very near the mushroom specimen, lots of roots, exposed and burried. I was harvesting Quercus ilex saplings from underneath the tree. Only found the pair of mushrooms growing next to each other

Cap; Biggest specimen was around 9cm, inrolled margin, flat-convex shape, slimy, pale tan buff with a darker central brown/beige coloration

Gills; Attached to stipe, crowded, pale in coloration with a light tan/beige coloration, brown stains on gills and droplets of water on gills

Stipe; More or less equal, around 1.3cm in diameter, smooth with a velvet like soft feeling, flakes around the apex of stipe, basal stipe has white rhizomorphs

Flesh; thick and white

Odour; Slightly like raddish
results.location_name: MCAST Institute of Agribusiness, Qormi, Malta

Stipe; Thin, equal, watery, very fragile and hollow, dark brown coloration,

results.notes: As in many other cases it was a question of chance to find this species. In the field I could only realise that it was a lirellate fungi/lichen, similar to some Hysteriaceae that collected recently, though the lirallae were very small. While trying to study it under the microscope, most of the attempts failed due to infertilness. Then I saw some apothecia with open discs on the opposite side of the small branch of shrub (6-7 mm in diameter) shown in Photo 1 and succeeded to observe the fertile part. results.notes:
Found in two places, one along Stevens Canyon Road, the other along Redwood Gulch Road. It appeared quite common. I saw about 30 fruitbodies, all growing on wood sticks on the ground, either solo or in small groups. The largest were about 6 cm across (shown in the first photo).

There seem to be only three dark gelatinous species found on the West Coast USA: Urnula padeniana, Urnula mexicana, and Pseudosarcosoma latahense. My microscopy is not complete, but based on the relatively small size and non-guttulate mature spores, I bet the third name is most likely.

results.notes:
This observation is for the one in the center with large bubbly apothecia.
Thallus greenish, probably too dark for ochrolechia species and L. allophana. Obviously, lecanora only growing on rock or conifers (this is Quercus agrifolia) can be eliminated. Thallus presence\color\shape eliminates polytropa, saligna, hagenii, dispersa and crenulata, margins not as in chlarotera or strobilina.
Apothecia not sparse as in expallens, too pale for circumborealis, cadubriae or argopholis, and lacking the thick bumpy rims of hybocarpa.
Thallus perhaps too green\dark for desmothenesii or cinereofusca, though specimen still moist.
Albelulla and chlarotera might not be in range here (?)
Substrate may be wrong for cenisia (?)

results.notes:
Growing on the trunk of an American Beech (Fagus grandifolia) tree on an east-facing slope above a lake.

Perennial.
Growths begin as a cluster of 10-or-so brackets, approximately the size of Trametes versicolor brackets (image not available). ‘Colonies’ gradually grow in the number of almost-horizontal brackets. Mature colonies form a ‘knot’ of overlapping brackets. Mature knots are approximately 3-4 inches wide, and occur as individual knots or knots growing adjacent to others.
Cross-section of knot shows pores; pore depth, up to 3mm.
Pore density: 3-4 pores/mm
In dormant phase, knots are gray with a brownish tone in sunlight and a purplish tone in shade. Brackets are ‘collapsed’ over each other; lobes leathery with a leathery texture and stiff, not particularly flexible.

Fruiting: September-November (in Barrow County, GA)
Fruiting sequence:
Week 1. Brackets begin to fruit by turning gray-white, multi-lobed growth with a discontinuous white pore surface.
Week 2. Brackets turn brown with bright white margins. The tops of brackets have a ‘metallic’ rusty iron-colored surface. Pore surfaces are still white (immature).
Week 3. The white margins of brackets begin to dull. Pore surfaces are turning gray as they mature.
Week 4. The bracket margins continue to darken. Pore surfaces have darkened considerably and are probably mature.
Week 5. The bracket margins are almost completely brown. Color of pore surfaces are unchanged from Week 4.

Note:
Original (2009) photograph of young colony.
Observations of fruiting sequence of knots taken in 2015; observations of pore surfaces for corresponding knots taken in 2016. Date of observation based on date of beginning of fruiting sequence in 2015.

results.notes:
On decaying skin of a California horse-chestnut’s seed. The cup is about 7 mm tall. “One mushroom is not a collection”, I guess especially not if the mushroom is a Hemimycena, but still it’s fun to examine.

Totally nonreactive in Melzer’s. No cheilo/pleuro/pileo-cystidia. Caulocystidia irregularly cylindrical. Pileipellis with diverticulate hyphae. Lacrymoid spores 7-9 × 3-4; basidia (24-30)+5 x (6-7). All this agrees with the description of Hemimycena pseudogracilis, and the photo in the Antonin-Nordeloos monograph looks similar enough too. The species is European, however; I don’t know if it’s been reported from North America.

My old Observation 91419 may be the same thing.
